<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

Now I have a clear picture:

**Structure:**
- dev/ (source): html (pug), scss, js, images, libs, manifest.json. No dev/sw.js.
- dist/ (output): built by gulp. manifest.json and sw.js exist in dist (manifest likely copied manually or by a step not in gulpfile).

**Gulp:** No task to copy manifest or sw to dist. No `default` or `build` task. `watch` starts server and watches. So manifest/sw in dist are either manual or from an old script.

**Pages:** Only index.pug. No about, contact, or other pages. Navbar uses variables.pug (navLink, otherLinks) with hash links only.

**PWA gaps:**
- manifest: scope and start_url are ""
- manifest: need valid start_url (e.g. "/" or "./index.html")
- No dev/sw.js - sw only in dist with wrong asset paths (../index.html, jquery-3.6.0.min.js, bootstrap.min.js, main-min.js, bootstrap.min.css - but build produces main.js concat with jquery, and libs.css/main.css)
- Gulp doesn't copy manifest or sw to dist
- head.pug: apple-touch-icon has typo .png.png
- HTTPS required for PWA (document in README)
- Offline fallback page optional

**Accessibility/contrast:**
- Nav link: `alt="val"` is wrong (alt is for images; use aria or remove)
- _theme: $secondry-color #9ca2c6 on $light-color #f3f3ff - need to check contrast
- $main-color rgb(187, 137, 57) - gold/brown on white - check
- Focus styles: no visible :focus styles in _style
- Skip link, landmark roles, heading order - need to check
- prefers-reduced-motion already present (good)

**README:** Basic; missing: project structure, all npm/gulp commands, PWA section, accessibility, contrast, how to add pages, env/deploy notes.

I'll create a comprehensive plan.
</details></think>

```json
{
  "plan": "# Trufla Project Enhancement Plan\n\n## Current state summary\n\n- **Stack:** Gulp 3, Pug, SCSS, jQuery, Bootstrap 4. Static server on port 6001.\n- **Source:** [dev/](dev/) (pug in &#96;dev/html/&#96;, SCSS in &#96;dev/scss/&#96;, JS in &#96;dev/js/&#96;, [dev/manifest.json](dev/manifest.json)).\n- **Output:** [dist/](dist/) built by gulp; **manifest and [dist/sw.js](dist/sw.js) are not produced by gulp** (likely copied manually). Only one page: [dev/html/index.pug](dev/html/index.pug).\n\n---\n\n## 1. Project structure and commands\n\n### 1.1 Folder structure (keep and document)\n\nKeep the current split (&#96;dev/&#96; = source, &#96;dist/&#96; = build). Add a small amount of structure for multiple pages:\n\n- **dev/html/** – add &#96;about.pug&#96;, &#96;contact.pug&#96; (and any future pages) next to &#96;index.pug&#96;.\n- **dev/html/pug/** – keep shared partials: &#96;head.pug&#96;, &#96;navbar.pug&#96;, &#96;footer.pug&#96;, &#96;scripts.pug&#96;, &#96;variables.pug&#96;.\n- Introduce a **shared layout** (e.g. &#96;dev/html/pug/layout.pug&#96;) that includes head, navbar, main block, footer, scripts so each page only sets &#96;title&#96;, optional &#96;bodyClass&#96;, and main content. This avoids repeating the same structure in every page.\n\n### 1.2 Gulp and npm commands\n\n**Gulpfile changes in [gulpfile.js](gulpfile.js):**\n\n- **HTML task:** Change source from &#96;dev/html/*.pug&#96; to &#96;dev/html/**/*.pug&#96; **or** explicitly list &#96;index.pug&#96;, &#96;about.pug&#96;, &#96;contact.pug&#96; so all root-level pug files are compiled to &#96;dist/&#96; (same name). Ensure only “page” pug files (not layout or partials) are compiled.\n- **New tasks:**  \n  - &#96;manifest&#96; – copy &#96;dev/manifest.json&#96; to &#96;dist/manifest.json&#96;.  \n  - &#96;sw&#96; – copy service worker from source to dist (recommend adding &#96;dev/sw.js&#96; and copying it to &#96;dist/sw.js&#96;).\n- **&#96;default&#96; task:** Run in order: &#96;html&#96;, &#96;css&#96;, &#96;libs&#96;, &#96;js&#96;, &#96;img&#96;, &#96;manifest&#96;, &#96;sw&#96; (so a single &#96;gulp&#96; builds everything including PWA assets).\n- **&#96;build&#96; task:** Alias for the same set (production build).\n- **&#96;watch&#96;:** Keep starting [server.js](server.js) and livereload; add &#96;gulp.watch('dev/manifest.json', ['manifest'])&#96; and &#96;gulp.watch('dev/sw.js', ['sw'])&#96; so PWA files update during development.\n\n**Package.json scripts in [package.json](package.json):**\n\n- &#96;\"start\"&#96;: run &#96;gulp watch&#96; (dev server + watch).\n- &#96;\"build\"&#96;: run &#96;gulp build&#96; (or &#96;gulp&#96; if default is the full build).\n- &#96;\"serve\"&#96;: optional; run a static server on &#96;dist&#96; only (e.g. &#96;npx serve dist&#96; or keep using your existing server script for production preview).\n\nResult: one-command dev (&#96;npm start&#96;), one-command build (&#96;npm run build&#96;), and PWA assets always built from source.\n\n---\n\n## 2. New pages (About, Contact, etc.)\n\n- **Layout:** Add [dev/html/pug/layout.pug](dev/html/pug/layout.pug) with: doctype, html, head include, body with header (navbar), &#96;block content&#96;, footer, scripts. Each page then &#96;extends layout&#96; and fills &#96;block content&#96; and sets &#96;title&#96; (and optional &#96;bodyClass&#96;).\n- **Pages:**  \n  - [dev/html/about.pug](dev/html/about.pug) – extend layout, title “About | Trufla”, simple about content (heading, text).  \n  - [dev/html/contact.pug](dev/html/contact.pug) – extend layout, title “Contact | Trufla”, contact info and/or a simple form (name, email, message). Form can post to &#96;#&#96; or a future endpoint; ensure labels and structure are accessible.\n- **Navigation:** In [dev/html/pug/variables.pug](dev/html/pug/variables.pug), change &#96;navLink&#96; to include paths and labels, e.g. &#96;[{ label: 'Payments', href: 'index.html' }, { label: 'Claims Assistance', href: '#' }, { label: 'About', href: 'about.html' }, { label: 'Contact', href: 'contact.html' }]&#96;. Contrast and accessibility\n\n### 5.1 Contrast\n\n- **Theme colors** in [dev/scss/scss_utilites/_theme.scss](dev/scss/scss_utilites/_theme.scss): &#96;$main-color&#96; (gold/brown), &#96;$secondry-color&#96; (#9ca2c6), &#96;$dark-color&#96; (#42415b), &#96;$light-color&#96; (#f3f3ff). Check text/background pairs with a contrast checker (e.g. WebAIM):\n  - Dark text on light: e.g. &#96;$dark-color&#96; on white / &#96;$light-color&#96; (aim ≥ 4.5:1 for body, ≥ 3:1 for large text).\n  - &#96;$secondry-color&#96; on &#96;$light-color&#96; (space-section bar): ensure ≥ 3:1 if it carries text.\n  - Buttons: &#96;$main-color&#96; / white text – verify ≥ 4.5:1.\n- **Hero:** White text on hero image – ensure overlay or image choice gives sufficient contrast; if not, add a semi-transparent overlay or darken image in CSS.\n- **Focus:** Add visible focus styles in SCSS (e.g. &#96;:focus-visible&#96; outline or box-shadow) for &#96;.nav-link&#96;, &#96;.btn&#96;, &#96;.scroll-top&#96;, and form controls so keyboard users can see focus. Avoid removing outline without a replacement.\n\n### 5.2 Accessibility\n\n- **Navbar [dev/html/pug/navbar.pug](dev/html/pug/navbar.pug):** Remove &#96;alt=\"val\"&#96; from links (alt is for images). Use link text for labels or &#96;aria-label&#96; only where necessary (e.g. “Phone: 555-555-5555”). Fix &#96;alt=\"val\"&#96; on nav links.\n- **Images:** Keep meaningful &#96;alt&#96; on logo and team images; decorative icons can use &#96;alt=\"\"&#96; or &#96;aria-hidden=\"true\"&#96;.\n- **Headings:** Ensure one &#96;h1&#96; per page and logical order (h1 → h2 → h3). About and Contact pages should have an appropriate h1.\n- **Skip link:** Add a “Skip to main content” link at the very start of body (visible on focus) that targets &#96;#main-content&#96; or the main landmark; add &#96;id=\"main-content\"&#96; to the main content wrapper in layout.\n- **Landmarks:** Use &#96;&lt;main&gt;&#96;, &#96;&lt;header&gt;&#96;, &#96;&lt;footer&gt;&#96;, &#96;&lt;nav&gt;&#96; (navbar already in header; ensure nav wraps the nav element).\n- **Scroll-top button:** Add &#96;aria-label=\"Scroll to top\"&#96; and ensure it’s focusable and visible on focus.\n- **Forms (contact):** Use &#96;&lt;label for=\"...\"&gt;&#96; for each input; associate labels with inputs; optional: add &#96;aria-describedby&#96; for error/hint text.\n- **Reduced motion:** You already have &#96;@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)&#96; for &#96;.scroll-top&#96;; keep it and ensure any other motion (e.g. scroll animation) is also reduced when preferred.\n\n---\n\n## 6.   head
```
    include pug/head

And in each page we do block head and set pageTitle... Actually when you extend, the layout is the base. So we need layout to define title from a variable. So we need to pass pageTitle from the extending page. In Pug you can do:
- var pageTitle = 'Home | Trufla'
at the top of the extending file, but that might not override in the layout. The standard way is block append head and then in the page put a title in block head. So layout has:
  head

  head
    include pug/head
    block head
      title Trufla Task
Then in about.pug we do:
  block head
    title About | Trufla
That replaces the default title. Good.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

In variables.pug I used a multi-line array with leading dashes - in Pug each line with a dash is a statement. So:
- var navLinks = [
-   { label: 'Payments', href: 'index.html' },
...
- ]
That might not parse - the dash on the next line might start a new statement. Let me check Pug syntax. In Pug, for multi-line you'd do:
- var navLinks = [
-   { label: 'Payments', href: 'index.html' },
-   ...
- ]
Actually the issue is the first line "- var navLinks = [" - then the next line "-   { label: ..." is a new statement (variable with invalid name). So we need one line or proper continuation. In Pug, you can do:
- var navLinks = [{ label: 'Payments', href: 'index.html' }, { label: 'Claims Assistance', href: 'index.html#team' }, { label: 'About', href: 'about.html' }, { label: 'Contact', href: 'contact.html' }]
Single line to be safe.
</details></think>

---


Summary of what was implemented:

## 1. Gulp and commands
- **`dev/sw.js`** – Service worker that caches `index.html`, `about.html`, `contact.html`, main CSS and JS (no references to missing files).
- **Gulp** – New tasks: `manifest` (copy `dev/manifest.json` → `dist`), `sw` (copy `dev/sw.js` → `dist`). New `default` and `build` tasks run: html, css, libs, js, img, manifest, sw. Watch updated to observe `manifest.json` and `sw.js`.
- **package.json** – Scripts: `npm start` → `gulp watch`, `npm run build` → `gulp build`, `npm run serve` → `node server.js`.

## 2. Layout and new pages
- **`dev/html/pug/layout.pug`** – Shared layout with head include, optional `block head`, skip link, header, `main#main-content`, footer, scripts.
- **`dev/html/index.pug`** – Refactored to `extends pug/layout` and `block content`; team section has `id="team"` for the nav link.
- **`dev/html/about.pug`** – About page with h1 and short content.
- **`dev/html/contact.pug`** – Contact page with h1 and form (name, email, message) with `<label for="...">` and `aria-label`.
- **Nav** – `variables.pug` has `navLinks` with `label` and `href` (Payments, Claims Assistance, About, Contact). `navbar.pug` uses those, brand links to `index.html`, “Get a Quote” to `contact.html`, and no `alt` on text links; phone link has `aria-label`.

## 3. PWA
- **`dev/manifest.json`** – `scope` set to `"./"`, `start_url` to `"./index.html"`; file formatted for readability.
- **`dev/html/pug/head.pug`** – Apple touch icon fixed (removed double `.png`).

## 4. Accessibility and contrast
- **Skip link** – “Skip to main content” at the top of the body, hidden until focused; targets `#main-content`.
- **Focus** – `:focus-visible` styles for `.nav-link`, `.btn`, `.scroll-top`, and form controls (outline/offset).
- **Scroll-to-top** – Markup changed to `<button>` with `aria-label="Scroll to top"`; SCSS keeps layout and adds button reset.
- **Hero** – `linear-gradient` overlay (using `$dark-color`) to improve contrast for white text.
- **_theme.scss** – Comment added about WCAG-oriented contrast.

## 5. README
- **README.md** – Rewritten to include: short description, demo link, tech stack, project structure, prerequisites, commands table, list of pages and how to add a new one, PWA section (manifest, SW, icons, HTTPS), accessibility and contrast, and original task section.

**Note:** `npm install` / `gulp build` can fail on your machine because of the old `node-sass` (and optional Python) dependency. The code and structure are in place; if you switch to `gulp-sass` with the `sass` package (Dart Sass), the build should run without that. The README documents the commands so you can run them once the environment is set up.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The user wants to restructure the project:

1. Rename `dev/html/pug` to `dev/components` and move it to `dev/` (so it becomes `dev/components/`)
2. Move layout(s) into a `layouts` folder - so we'd have something like `dev/layouts/` with layout.pug (and room for future layouts)

So the new structure would be:
- `dev/components/` - contains head.pug, navbar.pug, footer.pug, scripts.pug, variables.pug (the shared partials, no longer layout)
- `dev/layouts/` - contains layout.pug (and future layouts)

Then the pages in `dev/html/` (index.pug, about.pug, contact.pug) would need to:
- extend from the new location, e.g. `extends ../layouts/layout` or similar - but Pug extends paths are relative to the file, so from dev/html/index.pug we'd do `extends ../layouts/layout`
- the layout.pug would need to include components from the new path, e.g. `include ../components/head` etc.

Let me think about paths:
- Current: dev/html/index.pug extends pug/layout, and layout is in dev/html/pug/layout.pug. So "pug/layout" from dev/html/ means dev/html/pug/layout.pug.
- New: dev/html/index.pug extends ../layouts/layout → dev/layouts/layout.pug.
- Layout file dev/layouts/layout.pug includes head, navbar, footer, scripts. Those will be in dev/components/. So from dev/layouts/layout.pug we need include ../components/head, etc.

I need to:
1. Create dev/components/ and move head.pug, navbar.pug, footer.pug, scripts.pug, variables.pug there (from dev/html/pug/)
2. Create dev/layouts/ and move layout.pug there (from dev/html/pug/)
3. Update layout.pug to use correct include paths: include ../components/head, include ../components/navbar, include ../components/footer, include ../components/scripts
4. Update layout to extend or not - layout.pug doesn't extend anything, it's the base. So layout.pug stays as is but with new includes.
5. Update index.pug, about.pug, contact.pug to extend ../layouts/layout instead of pug/layout
6. navbar.pug includes variables - that's in the same folder as navbar, so in components we have variables.pug. So in navbar we do "include variables" (same folder). Good.
7. Delete the old dev/html/pug/ folder (or remove its contents after moving).

Let me also check - variables.pug is included by navbar.pug. So when we move both to dev/components/, navbar still does "include variables" (same directory). Good.

Implementing.
</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

Now I need to:
1. Update dev/html/index.pug, about.pug, contact.pug to use extends ../layouts/layout
2. Update gulpfile.js - the pug task may need to know where to find components/layouts. In Gulp we're just compiling dev/html/*.pug. When index.pug does "extends ../layouts/layout", Pug resolves that relative to the file being compiled - and the file is dev/html/index.pug, so ../layouts/layout means dev/layouts/layout.pug. But wait - when gulp-pug compiles, the "basedir" or working directory might affect how relative paths in extends/include are resolved. Typically in Pug, paths in "extends" and "include" are relative to the file that contains them. So from dev/html/index.pug, "extends ../layouts/layout" correctly points to dev/layouts/layout.pug. And layout.pug has "include ../components/head" - from dev/layouts/layout.pug, ../components/head is dev/components/head.pug. So we need to make sure gulp-pug is run with a base that allows these relative paths. Usually gulp-pug compiles each file and the paths in that file are relative to the file itself. So it should work.

Let me double-check: gulp.src('dev/html/*.pug') - so the files are in dev/html/. When we compile index.pug, it has "extends ../layouts/layout". In Pug, the path in extends is relative to the directory of the current file (dev/html/index.pug), so ../ goes to dev/, then layouts/layout is dev/layouts/layout. Yes.

3. Remove the old dev/html/pug/ folder (delete the files).
</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

Pug compile: when gulp runs, it compiles files from dev/html/*.pug. The path "extends ../layouts/layout" from dev/html/index.pug is relative to the file. In gulp-pug, by default the filename is used for resolution. I think we need to pass a basedir so that ".." is resolved correctly. Let me check - in Pug, when you have "extends ../layouts/layout", the path is relative to the current file's directory. So for dev/html/index.pug, the directory is dev/html/, and ../layouts/layout would be dev/layouts/layout.pug. So the basedir for the compilation might need to be the project root or the file's directory. Actually in pug, the relative path in extends is relative to the file. So when compiling dev/html/index.pug, the current file is dev/html/index.pug, so its directory is dev/html. So ../ is dev/, and ../layouts/layout is dev/layouts/layout. So it should work. Let me verify by checking gulp-pug options - we might need to set basedir to the project root so that dev/html/../layouts resolves. Actually in Node Pug, the way it works is that when you compile a file, the filename you pass is used for relative path resolution. So if we pass filename: 'dev/html/index.pug' (absolute or relative to cwd), then ../layouts/layout from that file would resolve relative to dev/html/. So ../ = dev/, layouts/layout = dev/layouts/layout. So we're good. I didn't change the gulp task - we still use gulp.src('dev/html/*.pug'). The only thing is that when pug compiles, it needs to find the extended file. The default behavior in gulp-pug is to set the filename to the relative path of the file, so when the file is at dev/html/index.pug, the filename might be set to that, and then relative resolution would be from that path. So ../layouts/layout from dev/html/index.pug should resolve to dev/layouts/layout.pug. I believe it works. We're done.
</details></think>

Summary of changes:

## Structure

**Before**
- `dev/html/pug/` – layout + shared partials (head, navbar, footer, scripts, variables)

**After**
- **`dev/components/`** – shared partials only:
  - `head.pug`, `navbar.pug`, `footer.pug`, `scripts.pug`, `variables.pug`
- **`dev/layouts/`** – layout(s):
  - `layout.pug` (includes from `../components/`)

Pages in `dev/html/` (index, about, contact) now use **`extends ../layouts/layout`** instead of `extends pug/layout`.

## File changes

1. **Created**
   - `dev/components/head.pug`, `navbar.pug`, `footer.pug`, `scripts.pug`, `variables.pug`
   - `dev/layouts/layout.pug` with `include ../components/head`, `../components/navbar`, etc.

2. **Updated**
   - `dev/html/index.pug`, `about.pug`, `contact.pug` – `extends ../layouts/layout`
   - **gulpfile.js** – watch now includes `dev/layouts/**/*.pug` and `dev/components/**/*.pug` so layout/component edits trigger an HTML rebuild
   - **README.md** – project structure and “Adding a new page” updated for `layouts/` and `components/`, plus a note on using another layout (e.g. `extends ../layouts/other`)

3. **Removed**
   - All files under `dev/html/pug/` (layout and component files moved out; empty `pug` folder can be deleted manually if it remains).

You can add more layouts under `dev/layouts/` (e.g. `dev/layouts/minimal.pug`) and use them in a page with `extends ../layouts/minimal`.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The user is getting an npm install error:
1. ENOTEMPTY when renaming node_modules/mozjpeg - this is often caused by a corrupted or partially installed node_modules, or file system issues during install
2. The mozjpeg package is typically a dependency of gulp-imagemin (image optimization)

The fix is usually to:
1. Remove node_modules completely
2. Optionally remove package-lock.json to get a fresh lockfile (or keep it and try again)
3. Run npm install again

If that still fails, we could also switch from gulp-imagemin (which pulls in native binaries like mozjpeg) to a lighter alternative, or use npm ci with a clean node_modules.

Let me suggest removing node_modules and package-lock.json, then reinstalling. I'll need to run terminal commands.
</details></think>

1. Use --legacy-peer-deps so npm ignores the peer dep and installs anyway (gulp 3 + gulp-autoprefixer 7 often still work)

3. Upgrade to Gulp 4 (bigger change)

Actually gulp-sass provides logError. So the API is: the return of require('gulp-sass')(require('sass')) has .sync() and .logError. So we're good. Let me run npm install again. ---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The "primordials is not defined" error happens when using Gulp 3 with Node 12+. It's a known issue - Gulp 3 uses graceful-fs that relies on Node internals that changed. Options:
1. Use npx node version manager to run with Node 10 or 11 for this project
2. Add a resolution/override for graceful-fs and related packages
3. Upgrade to Gulp 4 (more work but proper fix)

There's a known workaround: npm install graceful-fs@4 --save-dev and add an override, or use the "npx npm-force-resolutions" or in package.json overrides to force graceful-fs@4. Actually the issue is that "natives" package is used by old graceful-fs. So we need to force graceful-fs to 4.x. Let me add overrides in package.json to force graceful-fs@^4.2.0 so that vinyl-fs and others use it.
</details></think>

---

---


Summary of what was fixed:

## 1. **ENOTEMPTY / install failures**
- **Removed** `node_modules` and `package-lock.json`, then reinstalled so npm didn’t hit the stuck `mozjpeg`/`gifsicle` directories.
- **Dropped** `gulp-imagemin` so the image task no longer uses native binaries (mozjpeg, gifsicle, etc.) that were causing ENOTEMPTY. The **img** task now only **copies** `dev/images/*` to `dist/images` (no compression). You can add an image min step later if needed.

## 2. **Peer dependency conflict**
- **gulp-autoprefixer** was set to **^6.0.0** so it works with **Gulp 3** (v7 expects Gulp 4).

## 3. **node-sass / Python build failure**
- **Replaced node-sass with Dart Sass**: added **`sass`** and **`gulp-sass@^5.1.0`**, and in the gulpfile use:
  - `require('gulp-sass')(require('sass'))`
  - `sass.sync({ outputStyle: 'compressed' }).on('error', sass.logError)`
- No native build or Python is required.

## 4. **`primordials is not defined` (Gulp 3 on Node 21)**
- In **package.json** added:
  - `"overrides": { "graceful-fs": "^4.2.11" }`
- After `npm install`, Gulp 3 runs correctly on Node 21.

## 5. **Result**
- **`npm install`** completes successfully.
- **`npx gulp build`** runs and produces HTML, CSS, JS, images, manifest, and service worker.

You may see Sass deprecation messages about the legacy JS API and `@import`; they don’t stop the build. To get a clean install from scratch in the future, run:

```bash
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json && npm install
```

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The error is that `open` package v10+ is ESM-only, so `require('open')` doesn't work in a CommonJS file (server.js). I have two options:

1. Use dynamic import() in server.js - but that's async, so we'd need to call open inside the server.start callback with await or .then(). We can use import() which returns a promise.

2. Use an older version of `open` that supports CommonJS (open@8.x or 9.x used to work with require).

The simplest fix is to downgrade to `open` v8.x which still supports require(). Let me check - open v9 might have gone ESM. I'll use open@8.4.2 which is the last 8.x and supports CommonJS.
</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

I need to:
1. Add Poppins font - the head is in components/head.pug, so I could add the Google Font link there, or put it in the footer. The user's code had it in a style tag in the footer. I'll add the font link to head.pug so it's available site-wide, and use it for the footer. Or keep the footer self-contained with a style block - but that would override * to Poppins which might conflict with the rest of the site (Roboto). So I'll only apply Poppins to the footer section by using a class .footer-section and then in SCSS we use font-family for that. So no need to add a global * { font-family: Poppins }.
2. Footer pug: Convert the HTML to Pug, use project logo (./images/logo-placeholder.svg), use Bootstrap grid (container, row, col) + custom classes for the new footer. Keep the scroll-top button at the end.
3. SCSS: Add styles for the new footer section using theme variables - background $dark-color (dark), text white/light, links hover $main-color, input/button borders and bg slightly lighter, etc.

Let me build the footer. The layout has `<footer class="footer">` so the footer component is included inside that. So my new footer content will be inside .footer. I'll add a wrapper class .footer-section for the new dark footer block so we can style it (bg dark, etc.) and keep .scroll-top as a sibling for the fixed button.

Structure:
- .footer-section (dark bg, padding, grid content)
  - .container

      - col-lg-6: logo + newsletter
      - col-lg-6: three columns of links (Products, Resources, Company)

Summary of what was implemented:

## 1. **`dev/components/footer.pug`**
- **Layout:** Two main columns (Bootstrap `row`/`col`): left = logo + newsletter form, right = three link columns (Products, Resources, Company).
- **Logo:** Uses project logo `./images/logo-placeholder.svg` linking to `index.html`.
- **Newsletter:** Email input + Subscribe button with `aria-label` on the form.
- **Links:** Products, Resources, Company; “About” → `about.html`, “Contact Us” → `contact.html`; Careers with “HIRING” badge.
- **Footer bottom:** “© 2025 Trufla. All rights reserved.” and social icons (X, GitHub, LinkedIn, YouTube, Instagram) with `aria-label`s.
- **Scroll-to-top:** Existing button kept at the end.

## 2. **`dev/components/head.pug`**
- Added Google Fonts link for **Poppins** (weights 300–700) for the footer.

## 3. **Theme colors in `dev/scss/main.scss`**
- **`.footer-section`:** Background `$dark-color` (#42415b), white text, Poppins.
- **Logo:** `filter: brightness(0) invert(1)` so the SVG appears white on the dark background.
- **Links:** Default `rgba(255,255,255,0.7)`, hover `$main-color` (gold).
- **Input/button:** Slightly darker than footer via `darken($dark-color, 4%)`, border `rgba(255,255,255,0.1)`, input focus and button hover use `$main-color`.
- **Subscribe button hover:** `$main-color` background.
- **“HIRING” badge:** `$main-color` border and tint.
- **Footer bottom:** Top border `rgba(255,255,255,0.12)`; social link hover `$main-color`.
- **Focus:** `:focus-visible` styles for inputs, buttons, and social links.

The footer uses your existing theme (`$dark-color`, `$main-color`) and project logo; the scroll-to-top button is unchanged. Run `npm start` to view it.

<script>
    const openMenuBtn = document.getElementById('open-menu');
    const closeMenuBtn = document.getElementById('close-menu');
    
    function openMenu() {
        menu.classList.remove('max-md:w-0');
        menu.classList.add('max-md:w-full');
    }

    function closeMenu() {
        menu.classList.remove('max-md:w-full');
        menu.classList.add('max-md:w-0');
    }

    openMenuBtn.addEventListener('click', openMenu);
    closeMenuBtn.addEventListener('click', closeMenu);
    menuItems.forEach(item => {
        item.addEventListener('click', closeMenu);
    });
</script>

Summary of the hero updates:

## 1. **`dev/pages/index.pug`** (hero only)

- **Hero badge** – Pill above the headline: “Trusted templates for your business” with a small theme-colored dot.
- **Headline** – Same text: “Welcome to truWeb Templates” (now `.hero-title`, centered).
- **Paragraph** – Same copy, centered, with a max-width.
- **CTA** – “Get a Quote” as a link to `contact.html`, styled like the design’s primary button.
- **Feature row** – Three items with theme-colored dots: “Payments”, “Claims Assistance”, “Get a Quote”.

No nav or script was added; the layout’s navbar is unchanged.

## 2. **`dev/scss/main.scss`** (hero styles)

- **Layout** – Light background `#fafafa`, centered content, Poppins (already loaded for the footer).
- **Theme** – Badge dot and feature dots use `$main-color`; CTA uses `$dark-color` (dark button), hover slightly darker; focus uses `$main-color` outline.
- **Typography** – Large responsive title (e.g. 2.25rem → 3.75rem on md+), supporting text in a muted black.
- **Badge** – White pill, light border, rounded, inline-flex with dot + text.
- **CTA** – Inline-flex button/link, dark background, white text, rounded corners, hover and focus-visible states.
- **Features** – Flex row, centered, wrapping; each item is dot + label.
- **Responsive** – Tighter padding and smaller title on small screens; old hero overrides for `.welcome-title` / `.content-text` / `.col-8` removed and replaced with the new classes.

The hero now follows the light, centered style of the reference (badge, headline, subtext, CTA, feature bullets) and uses your theme colors and existing content. Run `npm start` to view it.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The compiled CSS lives in dist/css/main.css, and the image will be in dist/images/heroimg.jpg (copied by the img task from dev/images/). So from dist/css/main.css the path to the image is ../images/heroimg.jpg. In the source SCSS we have url("./../images/heroimg.jpg") - the path is relative to the SCSS file location. When gulp-sass compiles, it keeps the path as-is relative to the output CSS file... Actually no - in gulp the SCSS is in dev/scss/main.scss and the output is dist/css/main.css. So the url() in the source is relative to the source file by default in some compilers, but gulp-sass typically keeps the path as written. So "./../images/heroimg.jpg" from dev/scss/main.scss would resolve to dev/images/heroimg.jpg when the compiler tries to find the file - but the CSS output is in dist/css/, so when the browser loads dist/css/main.css it will resolve url("../images/heroimg.jpg") relative to the CSS file, i.e. dist/images/heroimg.jpg. So we need the path in the CSS output to be ../images/heroimg.jpg. In the source SCSS, if we write url("./../images/heroimg.jpg") the output CSS will have that same path, and from dist/css/main.css, ../ goes to dist/, then images/heroimg.jpg is dist/images/heroimg.jpg. So we need the URL in the compiled CSS to be ../images/heroimg.jpg. So in SCSS we should use url("../images/heroimg.jpg") - but wait, the SCSS file is at dev/scss/main.scss, so relative to that, ../ is dev/, and dev/images/heroimg.jpg exists. When sass compiles, it doesn't rewrite the path by default - it keeps url("../images/heroimg.jpg") in the output. So the output CSS (in dist/css/) would have url("../images/heroimg.jpg") which from dist/css/main.css points to dist/images/heroimg.jpg. So we need url("../images/heroimg.jpg") in the SCSS. Let me check - I used url("./../images/heroimg.jpg"). The "./" is redundant; "../images/heroimg.jpg" is the same. So the compiled output will be ../images/heroimg.jpg which is correct for dist/css/main.css. Good.
</details></think>

---


Summary of changes:

## Hero section – image background and overlay

**In `dev/scss/main.scss`:**

1. **Background image**  
   - Set `background-image` to `url("./../images/heroimg.jpg")` (compiled CSS lives in `dist/css/`, so the image is loaded from `dist/images/heroimg.jpg`).

2. **Overlay**  
   - Layered a dark gradient over the image with `linear-gradient(rgba(66, 65, 91, 0.65), rgba(66, 65, 91, 0.55)), url(...)` so the gradient (using your `$dark-color` #42415b) sits on top of the photo and keeps text readable.

3. **Background layout**  
   - `background-size: cover`, `background-position: center`, `background-repeat: no-repeat`, and a `min-height` (32rem → 36rem → 42rem by breakpoint) so the hero shows the image properly.

4. **Vertical centering**  
   - `display: flex` and `align-items: center` on `.hero-section` so the hero content is vertically centered in the block.

5. **Light text on dark overlay**  
   - Title and body: white / high-opacity white.  
   - Badge: semi-transparent white background and border.  
   - Feature labels: `rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.85)`.  
   - CTA: `$main-color` background, white text, hover to `$dark-color`; focus outline set to white for contrast.

The hero now uses `heroimg.jpg` as the background with a dark overlay and light, readable text. Run `npm start` or `gulp build` and open the site to see it.

Summary of changes:

## 1. **`dev/pages/index.pug`** – team section

- **Section header:** “Contact Us” eyebrow, “(H2) Our Team” as main title, intro paragraph (Lorem Ipsum) kept as in the design.
- **Cards:** Three cards, each with:
  - **Profile image:** Unsplash avatars (3 different portrait URLs).
  - **Content:** name, title, short bio (“Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing”), phone (555-555-555), email (email@email.com).
  - **Social:** LinkedIn (with your URL), Dribbble, Twitter (SVG icons and `aria-label`s).
- Content (name, title, phone, email, linkedin-style links) is unchanged; only layout and visuals were updated.

## 2. **`dev/scss/main.scss`** – team styles

- **Section:** Centered block (`.team-section-inner`), max-width 1170px.
- **Eyebrow:** “Contact Us” in `$main-color`, 1.125rem.
- **Title:** “(H2) Our Team” in `$dark-color`, responsive size.
- **Intro:** 60% width (90% on small screens), gray text, margin below.
- **Grid:** `.team-grid` – flex, wrap, gap 1.5rem, centered.
- **Cards (`.team-card`):**
  - Fixed width 16rem, white background, light gray border, rounded corners.
  - **Hover:** Border and background use `$dark-color`; name, role, bio, phone, email and social icons switch to white/light for contrast.
  - Circular image (6rem), name, role, bio, phone, email, then social row (LinkedIn, Dribbble, Twitter) with spacing and focus styles.

Theme colors (`$main-color`, `$dark-color`) are used instead of blue so the team section matches the rest of the site. Run `npm start` to view it.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The user wants to:
1. Create a 404 error page in dev/pages/ using the provided design (but adapted to the project - Pug, theme colors, Font Awesome for icons)
2. Handle 404 in server or gulp so that when a page doesn't exist, redirect/serve the 404 page

For a static site served by static-server (server.js), the server typically just serves files. If you request /foo.html and it doesn't exist, the server returns 404 with its own default response. To serve a custom 404 page we have two approaches:

1. **Server-side:** Configure the static server to use a custom 404 page. I need to check if "static-server" package supports a custom 404 file - many static servers look for a file named 404.html and serve it with 404 status when the path is not found.

2. **Gulp:** Gulp just builds files; it doesn't handle routing. So we need to either name the file 404.html (so that when deployed to GitHub Pages or similar, they serve it for unknown paths) or configure the dev server to serve 404.html for missing paths.

Let me check the static-server package - it's "static-server" on npm. I'll need to look at its API. Often static servers don't support custom 404; we might need to use a different server (e.g. express with static middleware and a catch-all that serves 404.html with 404 status) or just create 404.html and rely on deployment platforms (GitHub Pages, Netlify, etc.) to use it automatically when the file exists.

Actually, many static servers and hosting platforms (including GitHub Pages) automatically serve 404.html when a request hits a non-existent path. So:
1. Create dev/pages/404.pug that extends the layout and contains the 404 content. Build will output dist/404.html.
2. For the Node static-server package - I need to check if it supports custom 404. If not, we could replace server.js with a small Express app that serves dist/ statically and for any 404 serves 404.html with status 404.

Let me create:
1. dev/pages/404.pug - full page extending layout, with the 404 content, using theme colors instead of indigo, and Font Awesome for the arrow icon on "Contact support"
2. Ensure gulp builds 404.pug to 404.html (dev/pages/*.pug should already be picked up)
3. Update server.js to serve 404.html for missing paths - I'll check the static-server docs or use a simple Express server to have control

Checking static-server npm: it might not have custom 404. I'll use Express to serve static files and a catch-all route that sends 404.html with status 404.

Summary of what was implemented:

## 1. **`dev/pages/404.pug`**
- Extends the main layout (navbar + footer).
- **Title:** "Page Not Found | Trufla".
- **Content:** "404 Error" label, "Page Not Found" heading, short message, and two actions:
  - **Go back home** – link to `index.html` (primary button).
  - **Contact support** – link to `contact.html` with Font Awesome `fa-chevron-right` for the arrow (no inline SVG).
- Styled with your theme (e.g. `$main-color`, `$dark-color`) instead of indigo.

## 2. **`dev/scss/main.scss`** – 404 styles
- **`.error-page`** – Centered column, min-height 400px.
- **`.error-page-code`** – "404 Error" in `$main-color`.
- **`.error-page-title`** – "Page Not Found" in `$dark-color`, responsive size (e.g. 2.25rem / 3.75rem).
- **`.error-page-text`** – Gray supporting text.
- **`.error-page-actions`** – Flex row for the two buttons with gap.
- **`.error-page-btn-primary`** – Filled button (e.g. `$main-color`), hover to `$dark-color`.
- **`.error-page-btn-secondary`** – Outline-style, arrow icon with slight move on hover; `:focus-visible` and `:active` (scale) for accessibility and feedback.

## 3. **`server.js`** – 404 handling
- **static-server** is configured with `templates: { notFound: '404.html' }`.
- For any request that doesn’t match a file under `dist`, the server responds with **404 status** and the contents of **`dist/404.html`**.

**Build:** The HTML task already builds `dev/pages/*.pug`, so **`dist/404.html`** is produced automatically.

**Check:** Run `npm run build` then `npm run serve`, and open e.g. `http://localhost:6001/nonexistent` to see the 404 page.

_**User**_

can we use tailwing v3 in gulp js with this project ? 

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The user wants to add Tailwind CSS v3 to their existing Gulp-based project. I need to:

1. Install Tailwind CSS v3 and its peer dependency (often postcss, autoprefixer - though they already have gulp-autoprefixer)
2. Configure Tailwind - tailwind.config.js
3. Integrate with Gulp: either use gulp-postcss with tailwindcss and autoprefixer, or use the Tailwind CLI. The standard approach with Gulp is to use postcss with the tailwindcss postcss plugin.

Let me check their current gulp setup for CSS - they use gulp-sass, concat, autoprefixer. So they have SCSS. To add Tailwind v3:
- Option A: Add Tailwind as a PostCSS plugin and run it on the compiled CSS (after sass). So: scss -> css, then postcss with tailwind + autoprefixer. That way Tailwind's directives get processed.
- Option B: Create a separate entry that only has @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities; and process it with PostCSS to generate a tailwind.css, then concat with their main.css or link both. That's the typical approach - have a main CSS that includes Tailwind directives, process with PostCSS.

Actually the typical Tailwind setup is:
1. Have a source CSS file that contains:
   @tailwind base;
   @tailwind components;
   @tailwind utilities;
2. Process that file with PostCSS using the tailwindcss plugin (and autoprefixer)
3. Output the result

So we need to either:
- Add a new CSS pipeline that processes a tailwind source file with postcss (tailwind + autoprefixer), then concat with their existing main.css and libs.css, OR
- Add Tailwind's directives to one of their SCSS files and run postcss on the output - but Tailwind directives are not valid in SCSS, they need to be in plain CSS for PostCSS. So the clean approach is:
  1. Create a file e.g. dev/css/tailwind.css or dev/scss/tailwind-source.css with just the @tailwind directives
  2. In Gulp: a new task that takes that file, runs postcss with tailwind and autoprefixer, outputs to dist/css/tailwind.css (or we concat with main)
  3. In their layout/head they already load libs.css and main.css - they'd add tailwind.css, or we concat tailwind into main

Actually the simpler approach for "use Tailwind with existing project":
- Install: tailwindcss, postcss, gulp-postcss, autoprefixer (they have gulp-autoprefixer but for postcss we need the postcss plugin)
- Create tailwind.config.js with content pointing to their HTML/Pug output and any JS
- Create a small input CSS file with @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities;
- Gulp task: read that file, pipe through postcss([tailwindcss, autoprefixer]), output to dist/css/tailwind.css
- Add <link> to tailwind.css in head (after libs, before or after main - usually Tailwind last so utilities override)

Or we could merge Tailwind output with main.css - run postcss on a combined stream. The cleanest is separate tailwind.css so that existing SCSS pipeline is unchanged and Tailwind is additive.

Let me implement:
1. package.json: add tailwindcss, postcss, gulp-postcss, autoprefixer (as devDependencies)
2. tailwind.config.js: content: ['./dist/**/*.html', './dev/**/*.pug'] so it scans for class names
3. dev/css/tailwind.css (or dev/scss/tailwind.css - but Tailwind expects CSS) with the three @tailwind directives
4. gulpfile: require gulp-postcss, tailwindcss, autoprefixer; add a 'tailwind' task that reads dev/css/tailwind.css, pipes through postcss with tailwind and autoprefixer, writes to dist/css/tailwind.css
5. Add tailwind to default/build and watch; add link in head.pug to tailwind.css

One issue: tailwind.config.js content paths. If we point to dist/**/*.html, after first build we have HTML. But when building, the Pug files are in dev/pages and dev/components - so we should scan dev/**/*.pug for class names since that's where we'd add Tailwind classes. So content: ['./dev/**/*.pug', './dist/**/*.html'].

Implementing.
</details></think>

---


Summary of the Tailwind v3 + Gulp setup:

## 1. **Dependencies** (with `--legacy-peer-deps`)

- **tailwindcss@3**
- **postcss**
- **gulp-postcss**
- **autoprefixer** (for the PostCSS pipeline)

## 2. **Config and source**

- **`tailwind.config.js`**  
  - `content`: `['./dev/**/*.pug', './dist/**/*.html']` so Tailwind scans your Pug and built HTML and only generates classes you use.

- **`dev/css/tailwind.css`**  
  - Contains:
    - `@tailwind base;`
    - `@tailwind components;`
    - `@tailwind utilities;`

## 3. **Gulp**

- **`tailwind` task**  
  - Reads `dev/css/tailwind.css`  
  - Runs PostCSS with `tailwindcss` and `autoprefixer`  
  - Writes **`dist/css/tailwind.css`** (with source map)

- **Build**  
  - `gulp build` / `gulp` now run the `tailwind` task with the rest of the pipeline.

- **Watch**  
  - Tailwind re-runs when any of these change:
    - `dev/css/tailwind.css`
    - `tailwind.config.js`
    - `dev/**/*.pug`
    - `dist/**/*.html`

## 4. **Layout**

- **`dev/components/head.pug`**  
  - Includes:
    - `link(rel='stylesheet' href='css/tailwind.css')`  
  - Loaded after `main.css` so Tailwind utilities can override when needed.

## 5. **PWA**

- **`dev/sw.js`**  
  - `./css/tailwind.css` added to the list of cached assets.

---

**Usage**

- Use Tailwind classes in Pug as usual, e.g. `div(class="flex flex-col gap-4")` or `div.flex.flex-col.gap-4`.
- Run **`npm run build`** or **`gulp build`** to generate `dist/css/tailwind.css`.
- Run **`npm start`** for watch; editing Pug or `dev/css/tailwind.css` will rebuild Tailwind.

**Install (if someone clones the repo)**  
From the project root:

```bash
npm install --legacy-peer-deps
```

Then `gulp build` or `gulp watch` as above.

---

_**User**_

is the tailwind changes is watch, so when i edit the pug files , it will reflect automaticly?

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The user is asking if when they edit Pug files, the Tailwind output will update automatically - i.e. is the watch set up so that Tailwind re-runs when Pug files change?

Let me check what we set up. In the gulpfile we added:
gulp.watch(['dev/css/tailwind.css', 'tailwind.config.js', 'dev/**/*.pug', 'dist/**/*.html'], ['tailwind']);

So when dev/**/*.pug changes, the tailwind task runs. But there's a nuance: when you edit a Pug file, the **html** task also runs (from its own watch), which compiles Pug to HTML in dist/. So the order is:
1. User edits dev/pages/index.pug
2. Watch triggers both: html task (because we watch dev/pages/**/*.pug etc.) and tailwind task (because we watch dev/**/*.pug)
3. Html task runs first (or in parallel) and writes dist/index.html
4. Tailwind runs and scans content - it looks at dev/**/*.pug and dist/**/*.html

So when you edit a Pug file:
- The HTML will update (from the html task)
- Tailwind will re-run and scan the content. But Tailwind scans for class names in the content paths. The Pug source has the class names (e.g. class="flex ..."), so when we edit a Pug and add new Tailwind classes, the tailwind task runs (because dev/**/*.pug changed), and it will scan the Pug files and generate the new utility classes. So yes, it should work.

One potential issue: Gulp 3 runs tasks in parallel by default when you list them as dependencies. So when you save a Pug file, both 'html' and 'tailwind' might run. The tailwind task reads from dev/css/tailwind.css and dev/**/*.pug (via the tailwind config content). So Tailwind will see the updated Pug files (they're already saved to disk when the watch fires). So the new classes should be in the Pug files when Tailwind scans. So yes - when you edit Pug files, the watch will trigger the tailwind task and the generated tailwind.css will include any new classes you added. And the html task will regenerate the HTML. So both happen. Good.

I'll confirm by reading the gulpfile watch section and give a clear yes/no answer.
</details></think>

---


Yes. When you run `npm start` (or `gulp watch`), Tailwind is part of the watch.

From your `gulpfile.js`, the **tailwind** task runs when any of these change:

- **`dev/**/*.pug`** – any Pug file (pages, layouts, components)
- **`dev/css/tailwind.css`**
- **`tailwind.config.js`**
- **`dist/**/*.html`**

So when you edit a Pug file and add or change Tailwind classes (e.g. `class="flex gap-4"`), the **tailwind** task runs, rescans the content, and regenerates **`dist/css/tailwind.css`**. With livereload, the browser should refresh and show the update.

In short: editing Pug (or the other watched files) triggers Tailwind automatically during watch.

_**User**_

@/Users/mamdouhramadan/.cursor/projects/Users-mamdouhramadan-Documents-trufla-task/terminals/4.txt:248-411 I got this error , please fix 

---

_**Agent (model default, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The error is in the footer.pug file at line 5. The Pug lexer is choking on `max-w-[157px]` - it's interpreting the `[157` as something (maybe the start of an attribute?) and then "p" from "px" as unexpected text. So the issue is that in Pug, when you use dot notation for classes like `img.invert.h-10.w-auto.max-w-[157px]`, the square brackets in `max-w-[157px]` are being parsed incorrectly by Pug.

The fix is to not use the dot notation for that class. I should use the class attribute with a string instead for the img tag, so the Tailwind arbitrary value `max-w-[157px]` is in a string and won't be parsed as Pug syntax.

So change:
```
img.invert.h-10.w-auto.max-w-[157px](src="./images/logo-placeholder.svg" alt="Trufla - Home" width="157" height="40")
```
to:
```
img(class="invert h-10 w-auto max-w-[157px]" src="./images/logo-placeholder.svg" alt="Trufla - Home" width="157" height="40")
```

Let me do that fix.
</details></think>

---


Fixing the img line: Pug treats `[` in `max-w-[157px]` as syntax when using dot-class notation. Using a `class="..."` string for the image so the arbitrary value is parsed correctly.

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="edit_file_v2">

<details><summary>Tool use: **edit_file_v2** • Edit file: /Users/mamdouhramadan/Documents/trufla-task/dev/components/footer.pug</summary>

</details>

</tool-use>

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

That should fix it. The Pug lexer was interpreting `.max-w-[157px]` as class "max-w-" followed by something starting with "[", which it then parsed incorrectly. Using `class="invert h-10 w-auto max-w-[157px]"` keeps the whole thing inside a string so Pug doesn't try to parse the brackets.
</details></think>

---


The error came from Pug’s class shorthand: with `img.invert.h-10.w-auto.max-w-[157px]`, the `[` in `max-w-[157px]` is treated as Pug syntax (e.g. attribute brackets), so the lexer failed.

The logo image is now using a normal `class="..."` string:

`class="invert h-10 w-auto max-w-[157px]"`

so the arbitrary Tailwind value stays inside the string and the build should succeed. Run your Gulp (or build) task again to confirm.

---

tailwind classes not applied on the footer , the style not applied , 
please check tailwind confgration and instalations

The content paths are relative - they're relative to the config file location by default in Tailwind. So `./dev/**/*.pug` is relative to where tailwind.config.js is (project root), so that should be fine.

2. gulpfile.js: The tailwind task uses postcss with tailwindcss() but it doesn't pass the config path. By default, tailwindcss() will look for tailwind.config.js in the project root. So that should work.

3. One issue: the tailwind task outputs to `gulp.dest('dist/css')` - so the built file is dist/css/tailwind.css. And the HTML links to `css/tailwind.css` - so when viewing dist/index.html, the path would be dist/css/tailwind.css. Good.

Summary of what was wrong and what was changed:

**Cause**

1. **Duplicate footer** – The layout wrapped the footer in `<footer class="footer">`, and the footer component also output its own `<footer class="bg-black ...">`. So the visible footer was the inner one, but it was wrapped by an extra footer that could affect layout/specificity.
2. **Tailwind config** – The config wasn’t always resolved correctly from the Gulp task, and content paths could depend on the current working directory.

**Changes made**

1. **Layout (`dev/layouts/layout.pug`)**  
   - Removed the `<footer class="footer">` wrapper.  
   - The layout now only does `include ../components/footer`, so there is a single `<footer>` (the one from the component with the Tailwind classes).

2. **Gulp (`gulpfile.js`)**  
   - Passed an explicit config path to Tailwind:  
     `tailwindcss(path.join(__dirname, 'tailwind.config.js'))`  
   so the same config (and content paths) is used whenever Gulp runs.

3. **Tailwind config (`tailwind.config.js`)**  
   - Set `content` to absolute paths with `path.join(__dirname, 'dev/**/*.pug')` and `path.join(__dirname, 'dist/**/*.html')` so Tailwind always scans the right files no matter where the process is run from.

**What you should see**

- A single footer in the built HTML with classes like `bg-black text-white py-12 md:py-16 ...`.
- Tailwind utilities for the footer coming from `dist/css/tailwind.css`.

**What to do**

1. Rebuild: from the project root run `npm run build` (or `gulp build`).
2. Serve the built site from the `dist` folder (e.g. `npm run serve` or open `dist/index.html` via a local server) so `css/tailwind.css` loads correctly.
3. If you use `gulp watch`, run it from the project root so the Tailwind task and config paths work as intended.

After a fresh build and opening the app from `dist`, the footer should show the black background, white text, grid layout, and other Tailwind styles. If it still doesn’t, say whether you’re opening `dist/index.html` directly or through a server and which URL you use.

---


Primary and secondary are now in your Tailwind theme. You can use them like this:

**Primary (`#bb8939`)**  
- Background: `bg-primary`  
- Text: `text-primary`  
- Border: `border-primary`  
- Ring: `ring-primary`  
- Opacity: `bg-primary/50`, `text-primary/80`, etc.

**Secondary (`#42415b`, e.g. hover)**  
- Background: `bg-secondary`, `hover:bg-secondary`  
- Text: `text-secondary`, `hover:text-secondary`  
- Border: `border-secondary`, `hover:border-secondary`  
- Same pattern for focus: `focus:bg-secondary`, `focus:ring-secondary`, etc.

Examples:

```html
<button class="bg-primary text-white hover:bg-secondary border border-primary">
  Button
</button>
<div class="bg-primary/10 text-primary border border-primary">
  Card
</div>
```

Rebuild (or let your Tailwind build run) so the new utilities are in `dist/css/tailwind.css`.

Summary of what was done:

**1. Bootstrap removed**
- **gulpfile.js** – Libs task now only includes `reset.min.css`, `normalize.css`, and `font-awesome.css`. `bootstrap.css` and the `dev/libs/**/*.css` glob are no longer used.
- **dev/js/main.js** – Removed the old `.nav-link .icon` click handler (it targeted Bootstrap markup that no longer exists).

**2. Header built with Tailwind**
- **dev/components/navbar.pug** – Replaced Bootstrap navbar with a Tailwind header:
  - **header**: `bg-white border-b border-gray-200 sticky top-0 z-50`
  - **nav**: `max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8`, flex layout
  - **Logo**: link with `focus-visible:ring-2 ring-primary`
  - **Nav links**: `text-secondary hover:text-primary font-semibold`, hidden on small screens (`hidden md:block`)
  - **Phone link**: `flex items-center`, number visible from `sm` up (`hidden sm:inline`)
  - **CTA**: `bg-primary text-white hover:bg-secondary border-primary hover:border-secondary` (same theme as before)
  - **Bar under nav**: `h-12 bg-secondary` (same as previous `.space-section`), `hidden md:block`
- **dev/layouts/layout.pug** – Removed the extra `<header class="header">` wrapper; the navbar component now outputs the `<header>` itself.

**3. Header/navbar SCSS removed**
- **dev/scss/main.scss**:
  - Removed the whole “Start Navbar Style” / “End Navbar Style” block (`.header` and `.navbar`).
  - Removed `.nav-link` from the global focus-visible list (nav links use Tailwind `focus-visible:ring-2 ring-primary`).
  - In media queries, removed all rules that only targeted `.navbar-expand-lg`, `.navbar-nav`, and `.header .navbar`; kept `.container` and other non-header rules.

**4. _style.scss**
- **dev/scss/scss_utilites/_style.scss** – Left as-is. It only has `@import` for variables, fonts, and theme; there were no header-specific styles in this file.

Primary/secondary colors (`#bb8939` / `#42415b`) now come only from your Tailwind theme. The header is fully Tailwind-styled, and the build completes successfully without Bootstrap.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The 404 handling I wrote is wrong - express.static will already try to serve the file. So if the file doesn't exist, express.static won't serve it and we need a catch-all. Actually the order should be: first serve static, then for any request that wasn't handled we need to send 404. With express.static, if the file doesn't exist it calls next(). So we need a final app.get('*', ...) that sends 404. But that would catch ALL requests - including those that static already served. So we need the 404 handler to only run when nothing was sent. Actually with express, the order is: use(static) then get('*') - the get('*') will only run if no middleware sent a response. So static will serve files that exist and call next() for missing files. So the get('*') will run for missing files. But wait - express.static doesn't call next() when it serves a file; it sends the response. So when the file exists, response is sent. When the file doesn't exist, express.static calls next(). So we need a catch-all that sends 404. So the logic should be:

app.use(express.static(distPath, { setHeaders: ... }));

// Catch-all for 404 - only runs when static didn't find the file
app.get('*', function (req, res) {
  res.status(404).sendFile(path.join(distPath, '404.html'));
});

But that would send 404 for every request that static didn't handle - e.g. /some/nonexistent - and serve 404.html. Good. But for / we'd get index.html from static. For /index.html same. </details></think>

---


Summary of what was changed:

**1. Tailwind config (`tailwind.config.js`)**
- Switched content from `path.join(__dirname, 'dev/**/*.pug')` to `./dev/**/*.pug` and `./dist/**/*.html`.
- Tailwind resolves these relative to the config file, so scanning is consistent no matter how the build is run.
- Removed the `path` require.

**2. No caching in dev**

**Service worker (localhost):**
- In `dev/js/main.js`, the service worker is **not** registered on `localhost` or `127.0.0.1`, so the SW no longer serves cached CSS/JS in dev.
- On first load on localhost, any existing registration is **unregistered**, so old cached assets are no longer used.

**Dev server (`server.js`):**
- Replaced `static-server` with **Express** for the dev server.
- All responses from the dev server send **no-cache** headers:
  - `Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, proxy-revalidate`
  - `Pragma: no-cache`
  - `Expires: 0`
- So when you use `npm run serve` or `gulp watch` (which starts this server), the browser does not cache HTML, CSS, or JS.
- **Express** was added as a devDependency.

**What you should do**
1. **Rebuild:** `npm run build`
2. **Dev:** Use the app via the dev server: `npm run serve` or `npm run start` (gulp watch). Open `http://localhost:6001`.
3. **If Tailwind still looks wrong:** Hard refresh (e.g. Cmd+Shift+R / Ctrl+Shift+R) or clear site data for `localhost` once. On the next load, the updated script will unregister the old service worker and the new server will send no-cache headers.

Tailwind output in `dist/css/tailwind.css` already contains the expected utilities (e.g. `.bg-primary`, `.text-secondary`, `.max-w-7xl`). With the service worker disabled on localhost and the new dev server, you should always get the latest CSS after a build.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

I need to read the current .team-grid and .team-card styles in main.scss to understand the layout, then:
1. Make the grid 3 columns on large screens (no fixed width on the grid)
2. On small screens: horizontal scroll with ~1.75 "columns" visible (each card takes about 1/1.75 of container width so the next card peeks). This is typically done with:
   - A scrollable wrapper: overflow-x-auto, overflow-y-hidden, scroll-snap optional
   - Cards with min-width so they don't shrink: e.g. each card min-width: calc(100% / 1.75) or roughly 57vw
   - display: flex with flex-nowrap for the row of cards on small screen
   - On lg: display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);

I'll add Tailwind classes to the team grid in index.pug for the responsive grid + horizontal scroll, and adjust/remove conflicting SCSS for .team-grid and .team-card so the layout is controlled by Tailwind. Or I can do it all in SCSS. User said "without width" for the grid - meaning the grid container shouldn't have a fixed width (it can still be max-w-7xl). So:
- Large: grid with 3 equal columns (no fixed column width)
- Small: horizontal scroll, show 1.75 "columns" - so each card could be min-width: 57.14% (100/1.75) of the scroll container, so you see one full card and a bit of the next.

I'll implement with Tailwind where possible and SCSS for the 1.75 fractional width on small screens (Tailwind doesn't have 1.75 columns out of the box). Approach:
- On small screens: wrapper with overflow-x-auto overflow-y-hidden, grid with grid-template-columns: repeat(3, minmax(57.14%, 1fr)) or use flex: display flex; flex-nowrap; and each card flex: 0 0 57.14% (or min-width: 57.14%). Actually 1/1.75 = 0.5714 so each card takes 57.14% of the viewport/container so 1.75 cards are visible.
- On large (e.g. lg:): grid with 3 columns, no horizontal scroll.

Let me use Tailwind for the grid and add a custom style for the small-screen card width. Tailwind has:
- grid grid-cols-3 for lg
- For small we need overflow-x-auto, and cards with a min-width that gives 1.75 visible. We can use a custom class or arbitrary value: min-w-[57.14%] or use a fraction. Actually the user said "1.75 in small screen" - meaning 1.75 columns visible, so each column is 100/1.75. So each card min-width: 100/1.75 % = 57.142857%. We need the container to be the viewport (or full width) and the inner flex/grid to allow horizontal scroll. So:
  - .team-grid: on default (mobile) display flex; flex-nowrap; overflow-x-auto; gap; then on lg: display grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr); overflow visible.
  - .team-card: on default flex-shrink-0; min-width: 57.14% (or calc(100% / 1.75)); on lg: min-width auto.

I'll add this in the pug with Tailwind classes and one custom utility if needed. Tailwind's arbitrary value: min-w-[57.14%] works. And we need the grid wrapper to be overflow-x-auto on small and grid-cols-3 on lg. So:
  - team-grid: class="grid grid-cols-[repeat(3,minmax(0,1fr))] lg:grid-cols-3 overflow-x-auto lg:overflow-visible gap-4 lg:gap-6" - but on mobile we don't want grid with 3 cols, we want a row of cards with min-width. So:
  - On mobile: flex overflow-x-auto snap-x, each card flex-shrink-0 min-w-[57.14%] (or min-w-[calc(100%/1.75)])
  - On lg: grid grid-cols-3

So:
.team-grid: "flex flex-nowrap overflow-x-auto gap-4 lg:grid lg:grid-cols-3 lg:overflow-visible lg:flex-none"
.team-card: "flex-shrink-0 min-w-[57.14%] lg:min-w-0" (lg:min-w-0 so grid controls width)

Scroll snap is nice: add snap-x to the container and snap-center or snap-start to each card for smoother scroll. Let me add that too.

Here’s what was implemented:

**Team grid layout**

1. **Large screens (lg and up)**  
   - CSS Grid with **3 equal columns** (no fixed widths).  
   - `lg:grid lg:grid-cols-3 lg:overflow-visible` so the grid is static and doesn’t scroll.

2. **Small screens**  
   - **Horizontal scroll**: the row scrolls so about **1.75 cards** are visible (each card is 57.14% of the scroll container width, i.e. 100% ÷ 1.75).  
   - Classes used:  
     - **Container:** `flex flex-nowrap overflow-x-auto … snap-x snap-mandatory`  
     - **Cards:** `shrink-0 min-w-[57.14%] lg:min-w-0 snap-center`  
   - `-mx-4 px-4 sm:-mx-6 sm:px-6 lg:mx-0 lg:px-0` so the scroll reaches the edges on small screens and stays within the section on large.

3. **SCSS**  
   - `.team-grid`: removed `display: flex`, `flex-wrap`, `gap`, and `justify-content` so Tailwind controls layout.  
   - `.team-card`: removed `max-width: 100%` so the 57.14% width can apply on small screens.

**Result**

- **Large:** 3-column grid, no horizontal scroll.  
- **Small:** One main card plus a bit of the next (1.75 columns), with horizontal scroll and optional scroll-snap for card-by-card scrolling.

Run `npm run build` (already done) and check the team section at different viewport sizes to confirm.

use this snippet in home page in @dev/pages/index.pug with title "our client"
<div class="overflow-hidden w-full relative max-w-5xl mx-auto select-none">
    <div class="absolute left-0 top-0 h-full w-20 z-10 pointer-events-none bg-gradient-to-r from-white to-transparent"></div>

    <div class="marquee-inner flex will-change-transform min-w-[200%]">
        <div class="flex">
            <template id="logo-template">
                <img class="w-full h-full object-cover mx-6" draggable="false" />
            </template>

            <script>
                const logos = [
                    "slack",
                    "framer",
                    "netflix",
                    "google",
                    "linkedin",
                    "instagram",
                    "facebook",
                ];

                const track = document.currentScript.parentElement;
                const template = document.getElementById("logo-template");

                [...logos, ...logos].forEach((name) => {
                    const img = template.content.cloneNode(true).querySelector("img");
                    img.src = `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/prebuiltui/prebuiltui/main/assets/companyLogo/${name}.svg`;
                    img.alt = name.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + name.slice(1);
                    track.appendChild(img);
                });
            </script>
        </div>
    </div>

    <div class="absolute right-0 top-0 h-full w-20 md:w-40 z-10 pointer-events-none bg-gradient-to-l from-white to-transparent"></div>
</div>

Summary of what was added:

**1. "Our Clients" section in `dev/pages/index.pug`**
- Placed after the team section and before the "Why Choose truWeb" block.
- **Title block** (same pattern as Our Team):
  - **Eyebrow:** `Trusted by teams everywhere` (`.team-eyebrow` – small label in primary color).
  - **Title:** `Our Clients` (`.team-title` – main heading).
  - **Subtitle:** `Brands and organizations that use truWeb templates to streamline payments and claims.` (`.team-intro` – centered, muted text).
- **Marquee:** Your snippet implemented in Pug:
  - Wrapper: `overflow-hidden`, `max-w-5xl`, `mx-auto`, `select-none`.
  - Left/right gradient overlays (Tailwind `from-white` / `to-transparent`).
  - Inner marquee: `flex`, `min-w-[200%]`, logos rendered twice for a seamless loop.
  - Logos: slack, framer, netflix, google, linkedin, instagram, facebook (same SVGs from the prebuiltui repo), with `h-10`, `object-contain`, `mx-6`, `min-w-[80px]`.

**2. Marquee animation in `dev/scss/main.scss`**
- `.marquee-inner`: `animation: marqueeScroll 15s linear infinite`.
- `@keyframes marqueeScroll`: `translateX(0%)` → `translateX(-50%)` for a continuous scroll.
- `.clients-section`: padding using the existing `$padding-v` variable.

The section reuses `.team-eyebrow`, `.team-title`, and `.team-intro` so it matches the rest of the page. If you want the exact wording "Our Client" (singular), change the title text in the Pug file. Build completed successfully.

  - Password input (with `id="login-password"` and matching `for` on the label).

**Theme colors (primary/secondary):**

- **Submit button:** `bg-primary` and `hover:bg-secondary` instead of indigo.
- **Sign up link:** `text-primary` and `hover:underline` instead of indigo.
- **Input focus:** `focus:ring-primary` instead of `focus:ring-indigo-600`.

**Other details:**

- Form has `action="#"` and `method="post"` (you can change these when wiring a backend).
- Main has `min-h-[60vh]` so the form is vertically centered in a reasonable area.
- Labels are associated with inputs for accessibility.

Build completes successfully and outputs `dist/login.html`. Open `/login.html` (or `http://localhost:6001/login.html` when using the dev server) to view the page. If you add `dev/pages/signup.pug`, the “Sign up” link will point to `signup.html` once that page is built.

Dark mode is driven by **system preference** (`prefers-color-scheme: dark`). To use a class-based toggle instead, set `darkMode: 'class'` in `tailwind.config.js` and add/remove a `dark` class on `<html>` or `<body>` with JavaScript.

Summary of updates to the Contact page:

**`dev/pages/contact.pug`**

- Replaced the previous contact content with the new section and converted the markup to Pug.
- **Theme colors (replacing indigo):**
  - **Badge:** `border-gray-300 dark:border-gray-600`
  - **Links & accents:** `text-primary` with `hover:text-secondary` or `hover:underline`
  - **Icon circles:** `text-primary bg-primary/20` (replacing `text-indigo-500 bg-indigo-500/20`)
- **Copy:**
  - Email: `contact@trufla.example.com` with `mailto:contact@trufla.example.com`
  - Phone: `(+1) 234 - 4567 - 789` with `href="tel:+1234567789"`
  - Address: “221b Elementary Avenue, NY” left as-is
- **Dark mode:** `dark:text-gray-200` on the main block, `dark:text-gray-400` on supporting text, and `dark:border-gray-600` on the badge.
- **Layout:** `max-w-5xl`, responsive padding `p-6 sm:p-10`, and `gap-8` on the grid.

The old contact form was removed so the page is only this section. If you want the form back as well, say where it should go (e.g. below the three cards) and we can add it.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

I'll create:
1. dev/components/testimonials.pug - a component that expects `testimonials` to be in scope (passed when including). It will have the section wrapper, heading, subtitle, and grid of cards. Each card: stars (5x SVG with theme color), quote, avatar, name, role.
2. In index.pug I'll add the testimonials data and include the component between clients-section and section-three. I need to pass the variable - in Pug you can do:
   include ../components/testimonials
   but the component needs to receive testimonials. The way to "pass" data in Pug is to set a variable before include: the included file sees the same scope. So in index.pug we do:
   - var testimonials = [ {...}, {...} ]
   include ../components/testimonials
   And in testimonials.pug we use `each t in testimonials`.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

Pug include with a variable - when you do `- var testimonials = [...]` and then `include ../components/testimonials`, the included file is processed in the same scope, so `testimonials` is visible. Good.

One issue: in the component I used `each t in testimonials` - the variable must be defined before the include. It is. But the component file doesn't have access to the parent's block variables unless they're in the same scope. Actually in Pug, include literally injects the file content and the included file sees the current scope (variables defined in the parent). So we're good.

Let me double-check the quote interpolation: p(class="...") "#{t.quote}" - in Pug, for block content we need to use = or !=. So it should be p(class="...")= '"' + t.quote + '"' or we use interpolation in the block. In Pug, block content with #{} only works in certain contexts. Let me check - for a tag's text content we do "p= t.quote" or p #{t.quote}. So for quoted text we want: p(class="...") "#{t.quote}" - actually in Pug 2, the content after the tag can be a string with interpolation if we use = so: p(class="...")= `"${t.quote}"` or p(class="...")= '"' + t.quote + '"'. I'll use the backtick form for clarity.
</details></think>

---


Fixing quote output in the component: Pug block content doesn't interpolate #{} the same way.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

line-clamp-3 is a Tailwind utility that may need the line-clamp plugin in older Tailwind - in Tailwind 3.4+ line-clamp is built-in. Let me check - Tailwind v3 has line-clamp in the default config. We're good. Run build.
</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

Build succeeded. I'll give a short summary to the user.

---


Summary of what was added:

**1. Component: `dev/components/testimonials.pug`**
- Expects a `testimonials` array in the parent scope (each item: `quote`, `name`, `role`, `image`).
- Renders:
  - Section heading: “Our Testimonials”
  - Subtitle: “Hear from our satisfied customers about the benefits of using truWeb…”
  - Grid: 1 column on mobile, 2 on `md`, 3 on `lg`.
  - For each item: card with 5 star icons (using **primary** color: `fill-primary text-primary`), quoted text, avatar, name, role.
- Card styles: border, white/dark background, hover lift (`hover:-translate-y-1`), `line-clamp-3` on the quote.
- Dark mode: `dark:text-gray-100`, `dark:border-gray-700`, `dark:bg-gray-800`, `dark:text-gray-200`, `dark:text-gray-400`.

**2. Home page: `dev/pages/index.pug`**
- Defines a `testimonials` variable (array of 6 items) with truWeb-focused copy and roles (e.g. Claims Manager, Operations Lead, Compliance Officer, Customer Success, Head of Payments, Founder & CEO).
- Includes the component right after the clients marquee and before “Why Choose truWeb”:  
  `include ../components/testimonials`

**Usage**
- To change testimonials, edit the `testimonials` array in `index.pug`.
- To reuse the block on another page, set `testimonials` and then `include ../components/testimonials` (or the correct path).

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>

The user wants me to add this "About our apps" section to the home page. I need to:
1. Add the Poppins font - but the project already has Poppins in head.pug for the footer. I should check if we need to add the full weight range or if we can add it to the existing link. I'll add the font import to head.pug if the current one doesn't include all weights, or we can add a section-specific font scope. Actually the user provided a style block - the cleanest approach is to add the Google Font link in head.pug with the full range if not already there, and then add the section to index.pug. Using * { font-family: Poppins } would affect the whole site - the user said "use this in home page as well" so they might want this section styled with Poppins. The head already has "Poppins:wght@300;400;500;600;700" - I could extend to include the full range, or leave as is and the section will use the existing Poppins. I'll add the section and use a wrapper with font-Poppins if we have it, or the body might already use another font. Checking head - we have Poppins for footer. So the site might be Roboto for body. For this section we can add a class like "font-['Poppins',sans-serif]" via Tailwind arbitrary value, or ensure the font is loaded and use a wrapper. Actually the user's snippet has * { font-family: 'Poppins' } in a style tag - that would apply globally. I'll just add the section content to the home page and use our theme colors (primary instead of indigo). I won't add a global * { font-family } override since that could change the whole site; I'll add the section with optional Poppins on just this section if desired. Let me add the section and use primary for the icon boxes (bg-primary/10 border-primary or similar instead of indigo).
2. Convert the HTML to Pug and use theme colors: replace bg-indigo-50 border-indigo-200 with bg-primary/10 border-primary/30 or similar.
3. Place it on the home page - I'll put it after testimonials and before section-three, or after section-three. I'll put it after the clients section and before testimonials, or after testimonials. Looking at the flow: Hero, Team, Clients, Testimonials, Section-three (Why Choose, etc). "About our apps" fits as an about/features section - I'll put it after Testimonials and before Section-three.
4. Update the copy slightly for truWeb (templates, insurance, etc.) while keeping the structure.
</details></think>
